satisfaction <\s> I was induced to make the following experi-
ments in consequence of having lately read Dr. Herschells 
excellent paper on the same subject, published in the 95 
Vol. of philosophical transactions, where he has releated 
a great number of experiments, explaining a variety of 
phenomena relative to prismatic Rings; & must Acknowledge my obligations to this celebrated Author, for 
his simple but ingenious contrivance of viewing pris-
matic phenomena by means of the shadow of a black 
card; without which it is probable the following discoveries 
such as they are, would not have been made.
<s>Before proceeding farther, it may not be 
improper to explain the nature & use of shadows. 
Experim[en]t 1. If a piece of unsilvered looking glass plate is laid hori-
zontally on a table exposed to the light of a window, 
& if a piece of wire 3 or 4 inches long & 1/20 of an inch in 
diameter is held over it, two distinct shadows will be 
perceived, one of which falls on the upper external surface, 
& the other on the lower internal surface of the glass plate. 
if the diameter of the wire is less than the thickness of 
glass plate, the two shadows will be clear of each other; 
but if greater they will partly interfere, & as far as they 
overlap each other will form a darker shadow between them. 
Ex 2. if two pieces of plate glass of the same dimensions are 
laid on each other, & if two slips of wood about the thickness 
of a shilling are put between them one at each end, the 
same wire held over them will give four shadows, 
viz - one for each surface: but if the two slips are taken 
away, the two middle shadows will coalesce into one, 
because the two adjoining surfaces form but one as to sense.
